name: FF UI Nightlight (default theme -> night mode)
description: Inverts the Firefox UI, but restores images; adds small glow and drop shadows to hovered buttons/tabs. Does NOT affect the content area. This is for use with Firefox without a 'theme' or 'complete theme' (see additional info.)

user.name: jep-dev
user.about:
For Firefox users:
If you haven't heard, this November, 'global' CSS that affects your UI and internal addresses (about:*, chrome://*, etc.) will no longer work unless you apply them manually to your Firefox profile. For an explanation of this change, just search for 'Firefox Web Extensions'; I would post a specific link, but it's best if you look up the most recent information.
An additional note: both global and local styles sometimes clash with external styles in unpredictable ways. I've outlined a possible solution for GTK users in my 'Nightlight' theme notes, but QT is less accommodating, and there are too many more to count. The gist is that if you want night mode for your browser, you shouldn't use a dark Firefox "complete" theme or external theme before applying a filter-based stylesheet like 'Nightlight'. This way page contents that inherit their attributes - 'native' buttons, text fields, etc. - will be styled consistently, and any further issues will be easier to fix categorically instead of making small patches. If you have or need recommendations, feel free to message me.

additional_info:
If you still want to apply a theme, this will likely conflict with night mode themes, because it relies on inversion filters. Otherwise it is largely unintrusive, and compact enough to customize to your liking. It currently contains 10 rules, one style applied to each, and only two '!important' overrides. If this style conflicts with your extensions, theme, or other styles, please let me know - include a screenshot or description, a list of the addons that might be relevant, and your platform. 'Style settings' (install options) added! Works well with:
  • Hide Caption Titlebar Plus
  • Tab Tweaks
  • Vertical Toolbar (pictured)
  • Status-4-Evar
If you are using Linux, GTK themes may affect the default style. If you are using a dark theme like xfce-dusk, try disabling inversion. Alternatively, specify your theme in your Firefox launcher or terminal invocation as per https://unix.stackexchange.com/a/185115 - this is extremely useful and solves a lot of theme-related bugs/conflicts! It may take some experimentation to find what's best for you, but in general you want either a dark environment theme or inversion from this stylesheet.
